Airline or airport strikes are almost inevitable during the busy summer season. Air traffic control strikes can be particularly problematic, as they’ll affect flights both in and out of a country, and any planes flying over its airspace.

There’s little you can do, except to ensure your airline has the correct contact details for you so they can get in touch if there is a last-minute delay or cancellation. It’s also worth downloading your airline’s app, which will often contain information not available elsewhere.
Here are some of the potential strike hotspots:

A planned walkout by cabin crew members of the National Civil Aviation Flight Staff Union (SNPVAC) prompted easyJet to cancel 21 flights to and from Portugal this month between August 15 and 17. An easyJet UK spokesperson said that these flights were cancelled due to “the unnecessary strike action planned by the SNPVAC union and in order to minimise the impact of the disruption on the day of travel for our customers”.

The airline said it wanted to give customers as much notice as possible so they could make alternative plans, adding that all customers on affected flights will be eligible for a refund or a free transfer to a new flight.
“We also advise customers travelling to and from Portugal on 15, 16 and 17 August to check the status of their flights on the easyJet Flight Tracker,” the spokesperson added.
It’s worth bearing in mind that rail strikes could also affect your journey to or from UK airports, though there are currently none planned.

As well as strikes, there is the possibility of disruption caused by issues with passport e-gates. On Tuesday, May 7, the Home Office confirmed a “nationwide issue” with Border Force e-gates that caused huge queues at airports across the country, including Heathrow, Gatwick and Manchester. The issue was later resolved.

There are no strikes currently planned for France. The last strike involving French air traffic controllers, due to take place on April 24, was called off at the last minute after a pay deal was reached.

There may still be strikes by CGT-RATP affecting public transport in Paris — the union has served a strike notice that covers the period between February 5 to September 9 — but no strike dates have been announced yet. The French government is currently debating a bill that could prevent the strike from happening.
There are currently no airport or airline strikes planned in Italy.
There are currently no airport or airline strikes planned in Spain. In general, Spanish law requires minimum service levels to be met, which means the effect of strikes are usually limited.
There are currently no airport or airline strikes planned in Greece.

Strikes aren’t the only thing that could disrupt your holiday plans in 2024. The rules around taking liquids through airport security are changing, which may cause confusion and delays at airport security checks.

UK airports including Teesside and London City, and Shannon and Donegal in Ireland have lifted restrictions on liquids. It means that you can travel with up to two litres of liquids instead of the previous 100ml containers in plastic bags, and don’t need to remove your laptops or tablets for separate inspection. However, the former rules are still in place for major airports including Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted, Manchester, Newcastle and Edinburgh.

Meanwhile, issues at Boeing have impacted its production schedule, which means some airlines don’t have as many aircraft as they originally anticipated. Ryanair for example has cut some of its summer schedule because of the delay. Wizz Air has also had to cut its summer schedule because of required engine checks for its Airbus planes. The cumulative effect of this aircraft shortage means fewer flights, more expensive fares and potentially longer delays if an aircraft is taken out of service at the last minute.
• Boeing 737 Max: which airlines use them and how dangerous are they?

In the Middle East, airlines have had to amend their flight routes to avoid Iranian airspace after Israel launched retaliatory strikes. It means longer flight times on long-haul routes, especially those to Asia and Australia, and delays due to congestion in the air. Those with a transit in the Middle East may also see an increase in the possibility of missed flight connections if there are delays.

And if air travel wasn’t already blighted with enough obstacles, there may also be further protests by Just Stop Oil on the horizon. The activist group has already targeted UK airports this summer, including Stansted, where activists sprayed two private jets were sprayed with orange paint. In July, protesters blocked a security gate at Gatwick airport’s south terminal using suitcases with lock-on devices. The nature of Just Stop Oil’s protests means that any further action this summer will be unexpected, but the UK’s biggest and busiest airports and roads leading to them will likely be targets.

Air traffic control strikes and those by airport staff not directly employed by an airline are considered “extraordinary circumstances”, which means you won’t be due any compensation from the airline. However, airlines still have certain legal obligations and a duty of care if you’re already travelling.

If your flight is cancelled then the airline needs to either offer you a full refund for the journey, as well as for any affected return flights on the same booking, to be reimbursed within seven days, or offer you an alternative flight, including with a rival airline in some cases.
• Everything you need to know about compensation for cancelled and delayed flights

If your flight is delayed for an extended period, the airline needs to provide you with a reasonable amount of food and drink, a means for you to communicate, accommodation if your flight isn’t until the next day, and transfers to and from the accommodation.
In some cases, you’ll be provided vouchers for these items but often you are expected to claim back reasonable expenses from the airline afterwards, so keep your receipts.

You could still end up with out-of-pocket costs and, in this instance, a comprehensive travel insurance policy may be handy. Whether you’ll get a payout will depend on your coverage, so check the small print. Also, make sure you get something in writing from the airline to confirm the cause of the delay or cancellation.
• A guide to travel insurance: everything you need to know

On Friday, July 5, Heathrow Terminal 2 was evacuated by emergency services after the Metropolitan Police was alerted to a “suspicious item that needed to be checked out”. The incident was investigated and resolved, with no further action taken, but passengers affected by the evacuation were instructed to check with their airline regarding any disruption to their flights.

Airport evacuations such as this one are, on the whole, uncommon. However, in case of an emergency, airports do have plans in place for mass evacuations, and you should follow all instructions given by airport and airline staff. Following the evacuation, airports and airlines should keep you informed on any developments via their official channels.

If your flight is delayed or cancelled as a result of the evacuation, you should check your airline’s policies to see if it offers any compensation or refunds in this case. Passengers should also consult their travel insurance policy details, as some providers might provide compensation for any disruption incurred as a result of the evacuation.

text: Thousands of counter-protesters have taken to the streets across England, outnumbering far-right demonstrators.

Crowds of anti-racist protesters have gathered in Bristol, Liverpool, Birmingham and Walthamstow to counter up to 100 far-right rallies which were planned for this evening. The Times has reporters on the ground at a number of locations. Follow for live updates.
Chris Webb, the MP for Blackpool South, came to watch the protest in his town — accusing some of those taking part of seeking TikTok fame.

The Labour politician told The Times: “This is a community that has felt neglected and is on hard times. Whilst I understand some people have legitimate concerns regarding immigration policy, coming down [here] for intimidation and thuggery won’t be tolerated.

“Today it’s mainly been young people trying to get TikTok famous … we’ve heard racist chants, but on the whole it’s more people interested in their community. Unfortunately we have a small group of individuals just wanting to cause harm and disruption.”

Though the majority of people out on the streets of Liverpool tonight were there to demonstrate their support for the values of multiculturalism, a small group of would-be far-right protesters lurked across the street (Constance Kampfner writes).

One man was seen circling around a young south Asian woman chanting “Tommy Robinson” before being escorted away by police. Mostly, however, they stood back, hoods up, assessing the scene. They were clearly outnumbered, by both police and anti-racism demonstrators.
Residents in Finchley have complained to their MP that “so-called anti-fascist” groups at rallies in the streets were “clearly antisemitic” (Tom Witherow writes).

Sarah Sackman, a Labour MP and the solicitor general, said she had made reports to the police and the Community Service Trust, a charity which provides security to the Jewish community. “Concerned residents have shared posts with my office relating to so called ‘anti-fascist’ groups in Finchley which are clearly antisemitic,” the MP said. “I will not amplify or platform those voices. Instead I have reported them to the police and CST. I advise others to do the same.

“I’ve said it once and I’ll say it again. Whether it’s the far right or far left there can be zero tolerance for antisemitism, Islamophobia or racism in any form. There is no place for such hate in our community.” Up and down the country, many of those protesting against the far right have worn face masks, sung pro-Palestine chants and waved Palestinian flags.
In Brighton, a group of four right-wing protesters have been significantly outnumbered by thousands of counter-demonstrators.

The four were protected by a dozen police officers, who created a cordon around them with two lines of officers ensuring they were separated from the crowd. Protesters chanted “Fascist scum, off our streets” at the group. The counter-demonstration was so large that a bus became trapped in the crowd, and was still going strong at 9.45pm.

Hundreds of counter-protesters sang and chanted outside the Asylum Welcome centre in Oxford and asylum seekers who had retreated to their rooms in a nearby hotel stepped out to wave to well-wishers (Larisa Brown writes).

Mark Goldring, director of the organisation, said as many as 400 counter-protesters had turned up and no one from the far right could be seen. He said it had all been a “complete false alarm but all credit to the police because they took it very seriously”.

He said that the counter-protesters had demonstrated the “power of local people taking to the streets and showing that they cared”. He said he would be back at his office, on the list of places to be targeted by anti-immigration protesters on Wednesday night, first thing Thursday morning to continue his work.
A person thought to be an anti-fascist protester has been arrested following a scuffle in a car park in Dover.

A rumoured far-right protest outside an address listed as an immigration centre has not materialised. However there is a large police presence and an ominous atmosphere as small groups of men, who may or may not be involved in the far right, attempt to film the counter-protesters who are concealing their identities.
The Metropolitan Police has said it will move officers in numbers to arrest a group of people for anti-social behaviour, after they threw bottles at police.

On Twitter, the force said: “Approximately 50 people have gathered in North End Road, Croydon. They’ve made clear their intention is to cause disruption & fuel disorder. They’ve dragged and thrown objects down the road and thrown bottles at officers. This is not linked to protest, this appears to be pure anti-social behaviour.”
Images on social media showed men dressed all in black running up and down main roads.
A young Muslim man told The Times that he had been shocked by scenes of violence that unfolded in Liverpool last week (Constance Kampfner writes).

“This stuff doesn’t happen in Liverpool,” he said. “We’ve always been one community, we’ve always felt neglected by the rest of the country. But those people last week were sheep just jumping on the bandwagon.” He said they had gathered to defend those who “have run away from wars, from bombs and who are now getting terrorised here as well”.

Anton Galfarsoro, 19, a student, had come out with his father to show that last week’s rioters “don’t represent our city”. He said: “There’s too many people that we accept as quiet racists but we should call them out for what they are.”
If the dominant sounds of last week’s riots were of smashing glass and racist chants, the scene in Liverpool tonight was a stark contrast (Constance Kampfner writes).

The tune of “give peace a chance” blasting out of a shopping trolley was a gentler welcome on the city streets, where hundreds of people gathered outside an asylum centre in a show of defiance to the far right. Signs attached to metal railings and being held in the air boasted slogans including: “Welcome immigrants: deport fascists!” and “Merseyside pensioners fight back.”

Cars honked as they drove past the tambourine-thumping group which stretched down Overbury Street, a mile from the city centre. A few young men wearing masks were seen giving the middle finger to police as a helicopter circled overhead, but officers — with their helmets resting strapped to carabiners on their hips — seemed relieved that that was as bad as it seemed to get.
In Blackpool, seven protesters mounted a roundabout in the town centre, holding up a Union Jack and St George’s flag to a cheering crowd of around 100.

With Blackpool Tower visible in the background, they sang “England till I die” and chanted: “This is f***ing England.” Another protester, looking on, shouted: “There’s no black in the Union Jack.” Meanwhile, a woman dressed in a nightie and slippers marched up to the protest and ordered several of her children home.
Hundreds of counter-demonstrators have turned out in Bristol in response to planned anti-immigration protests.

Scores of anti-racism protesters gathered around Castle Park and Old Market in the city centre. There are also counter-protesters in Brighton as restaurants including a kebab shop and noodle bar were boarded up along the road where protests were expected to take place. Police appeared to escort a few men towards the train station as counter-protesters followed them chanting.
“There are many, many more of us the you,” chant peace protesters in Southend-On-Sea at nobody in particular.

After an earlier flare-up was diffused, the situation has calmed. But the police tactic of creating a partial barrier between two ends of Hamlet Court Road is causing some confusion. Counter-demonstrators are facing up and chanting at the other side — however, one protester who has just walked from one end to the other says: “There are no far-right down there.”

Around 500 counter-protesters who had been stood outside of an immigration centre in the Jewellery Quarter of Birmingham began marching towards the city centre chanting “fascist scum out of Brum” on Wednesday evening.
Families were dressed in matching balaclavas and said they had decided to attend the counter-protest to “protect their community in numbers”. One masked boy was just ten years old.

The peaceful turnout was in response to social media posts that suggested that a far-right presence would return to the city in coordination with other nationalist rallies reportedly planned across the UK tonight. One black protester from Leicester said he had joined the group “to defend what’s right, adding “for me I can’t leave the security of my community to others”.
A couple of dozen counter protesters are holding signs in a car park in Dover, where there is a heavy police presence. Rumours of a major far-right protest in the town have so far not materialised.
There are lots of people walking the streets and sitting in cars and it feels like they are sizing up if anything is going to happen in Dover tonight.

Raphaël Arnault, a prominent French anti-fascist activist who was recently elected to the country’s National Assembly, said on Twitter that he had come to London to support counter-demonstrations after the riots at the weekend.

Arnault, who founded the French group Jeune Garde (Young Guard), said: “So I’m heading to London to support local anti-fascist comrades in the face of racist riots and targeted attacks. Young Guard Mode Activated.” The Jeune Garde have been involved in regular clashes with the far-right in France.
He later posted a photo from Walthamstow, where a significant counter-demonstration gathered outside of an immigration lawyer’s office. Arnault added: “The resistance is on!”
A man has been arrested on suspicion of failing to comply with a Section 60AA order after refusing to remove his face covering, police said.

Cleveland police introduced the special power following disorder in Hartlepool and Middlesborough over the past week. The man was challenged by officers on Park Lane in Middlesborough on Wednesday evening and asked to remove a face covering. Separately, a man has been arrested near the site of a planned protest in Blackpool.
Tempers flared between anti-immigration demonstrators and anti-racist protesters in Aldershot, with video footage showing a line of police officers acting as a barrier between the two sides.

As protesters held up “Stand Up To Racism” placards and chanted “refugees are welcome here”, an anti-immigration group across the road chanted back “stop the boats”. At one point, some in the anti-immigration party stopped traffic to walk toward the anti-racism group and angrily shout at them, spurring dozens of police officers to rush into the road to prevent the groups from getting too close to one another.

One individual with the anti-immigration group was spoken to by two officers, but it is unclear if any criminal action was taken against him. There appeared to be far more counter-protesters than those in the anti-immigration group.
Counter-protesters in Harrow joked that they had “no protests to counter” after far-right groups failed to show up at the town’s immigration centre.

“We’ve scared them off”, one anti-fascist activist said, adding: “Either that or they’re all down the pub loading up on beer before coming here.” About 200 people gathered to chant and give speeches in support of immigration and refugees. Riot vans and police cars were stationed next to the demonstration but officers were confident that no far-right groups were nearby.

One policeman said at about 7:30pm that the Met had officers monitoring the local pubs for trouble and there were no signs that disorder was due. The force issued a Section 60 order giving officers to powers to stop and search and requiring people to remove face masks. More than a dozen men on the outskirts of the group had black face coverings and balaclavas on.

In Portsmouth, around 75 right-wing protesters have gathered on a main road near the port. On videos posted to social media, protesters, some wearing balaclavas, could be heard shouting “save our kids”, and stopping traffic.
Three riot vans of police are attempting to move the protest off the M275 after they blocked the road. Some protesters could be heard taunting police.

A small group of people, including some anti-fascist demonstrators, have gathered at the site of an expected protest near an immigration centre in Middlesbrough, but no protesters had assembled ten minutes after the planned start time.

In the residential streets nearby, security guards and dozens of residents stood outside a mosque while other people appeared to be on guard on Parliament Road, which saw significant damage, including a burnt-out car, during Sunday’s riot.

Meanwhile, hundreds of counter-protesters have assembled directly outside an immigration advice centre in Birmingham’s Jewellery Quarter, holding banners reading “Oppose Tommy Robinson”, “Bigots out of Brum” and “Stamp out Islamophobia”.
Tensions briefly erupted in Southend-on-Sea after a man in a black hood and wearing sunglasses was singled out by the crowd as a possible far-right demonstrator.

Police, who have had little to do at the protest so far, sprung into action and pulled the man away.Officers have formed a barricade across Hamlet Court Road, a busy shopping street, with counter-demonstrators on one side and a rumoured anti-immigrant faction gathering on the other. For all the good feeling so far, the situation feels fraught.

About 50 people, mostly young men, turned up to an immigration solicitor’s office in Blackpool, a few streets away from its seafront. Some wore balaclavas over their faces. They were watched by a police patrol car stationed outside the office.

One man, 31, who declined to be named, said: “I wanted to show my face today because this isn’t about the far right. The government has let all these illegals in and no-one knows what is going on. Where’s the fairness?”

He claimed that immigrants get “free benefits and free hotels”, adding: “We’re not saying no to them, we’re saying we’ve taken enough.” Officers brought out four police dogs to try and push the protesters back in Blackpool, after one man was knocked to the floor and arrested.

Police have arrested three people for public-order offences during a protest in Northampton. The suspects are in custody, police confirmed, adding that no members of the public or police officers were injured.

Around 150 counter-protesters had gathered peacefully at the junction of Kettering Road and Clare Street. Northamptonshire police confirmed that officers were in attendance. They are now asking people to completely avoid the area around the junction where a large crowd has gathered.

The director of one of the organisations that is the target of tonight’s riots said that anti-racism protesters had gathered outside his office and at a nearby local asylum hotel and so far it was “all calm” (Larisa Brown writes).

Mark Goldring, director of Asylum Welcome in Oxford, said he had been forced to close the office this afternoon but continued to run services for clients. “We have just had to lock it up and abandon it. We don’t know whether there will be ten protesters or 500,” he said.

He said his concern was that if the riot escalated there would be “no way out” because the office is in a courtyard. He added that he felt the organisation’s work was “more important than ever” and he had been overwhelmed by support.
The shops might be boarded up but it is a festival atmosphere in the Westcliff area of Southend-on-Sea in Essex (Mario Ledwith writes).

After news of a possible far-right demonstration spread, shops closed their doors for the evening, fearing disorder. By 8pm, several hundred counter-demonstrators had amassed at a junction close to an immigration legal office, included on a list of targets. Armed with a megaphone, a cheerleader is taking the crowd through chants of “Nazi scum, off our streets” and “This is what community looks like”. Passing motorists are beeping their horns and people are passing out slices of pizza from one of the few shops still open, amid a large police presence.
Outside the Asylum Link centre on Overbury Street in Liverpool, supporters of the charity filled the road following reports a protest was due to be held outside.

A police van blocked off the road as hundreds turned out to protect the building, which had boards over the windows. Placards were held by members of the crowd including ones which read “Nans against Nazis”, “Merseyside pensioners fight back” and “When the poor blame the poor only the rich win”. Signs placed on the fence around the building said “Love not hate” and “One human family”.

Dozens of protesters holding “Stand Up To Racism” posters have gathered outside Aldershot Enterprise Centre. They chanted and held banners reading “Refugees welcome. Stop the far right.” A few of them wore face masks.

Several police officers stood close by. A smaller group, some masked, congregated outside Yeomans Nissan Aldershot, opposite the road. Some of them shouted back angrily at the Stand Up To Racism group.
In Liverpool, Bristol, Newcastle and other cities, rumoured far-right protests were heavily outnumbered by counter-demonstrations.

In Liverpool, counter-protesters holding anti-racist placards and chanting “refugees welcome here” gathered outside an asylum-seeker support centre which had been listed as a target for the far right. The building had been boarded up by volunteers but a large crowd of peaceful protesters stood outside. Several women held up signs reading “nans against Nazis”. A dispersal order issued by Merseyside police will remain in place across south Liverpool until 7pm tomorrow.
There is a heavy security presence around the station in Dover, where rumours had spread on social media about a protest outside an immigration advice centre this evening.

At this stage there seems to be no disorder in the Kent town. The “immigration centre” in fact left the address some months ago and the premises is now being used for unrelated purposes. The Kent town has become a flashpoint because boats of migrants land on UK shores there.
Cumbria Police arrested two men on suspicion of public order offences — including using threatening words or behaviour intended to stir up religious hatred — relating to online activity.

A 41-year-old man from Carlisle was arrested over the alleged posting online of content encouraging violence against police officers and promoting public disorder, and a 40-year-old man from Carlisle was arrested in connection with the alleged posting of hate-related content online.

Both men are in police custody and Chief Superintendent Carl Patrick said: “Where there is evidence of people inciting hatred or promoting violence on our streets, our officers will not hesitate to take action. We will continue to prioritise the safety of the public and anyone involved in criminality can expect to be dealt with robustly.”
The government is working with football clubs to ban far-right rioters from matches, the i newspaper has reported.

Senior ministers are looking at using an existing law around football banning orders to prevent convicted anti-immigration rioters from attending matches, the paper reports. Any fans taking part in disorder such as throwing missiles could be banned from matches and the government is working with individual football clubs to facilitate this, the outlet understands.
Westminster security staff are in touch with MPs who could face riots near their offices on Wednesday night, the PA news agency understands.

Sir Lindsay Hoyle, the commons speaker, has told MPs to “exercise caution” amid fears that immigration and asylum assistance offices could be among the targets. MPs are thought to have been told “home working” is one option to bolster their security and a Commons spokesman has warned MPs’ safety “is fundamental to our democracy”.

According to sources, the letters — sent to all MPs — read: “The Parliamentary Security Department have reached out to members who have offices in close proximity to these plannecd demonstrations, to make them aware. Other offices — particularly those with prominent and easily identifiable locations — may wish to consider their security protocols.”
A crowd of men in Walthamstow were seen in videos on social media squaring off with police.

Dozens of shops and businesses in the district shut early, with many seen boarded up by 6pm. A group of counter-protesters congregated near the station after rumours of a far-right riot spread. At one point on a video live-streamed on TikTok, a small group of men who had broken away could be heard chanting Allahu akbar (“God is greatest”). However others urged them to stop.

At lunchtime Stella Creasy, the local MP, said Walthamstow Central Station would remain open, but warned there would be crowd-control measures in place. Hundreds of counter-demonstrators have gathered in the area, chanting “whose streets? our streets!” and “free Palestine”. Nearby, one person wearing a skull balaclava has been stopped and is being searched by police.

The King has asked to be kept updated daily on protests planned around the UK, Sky News has reported. King Charles is said to be engaging privately in the issues it has generated, the broadcaster understands.
It comes before what is thought could be the most intense night of protests, with some 100 planned across the country.
The publication of the names of immigration law firms as potential targets for disorder could be considered a terrorism offence, the director of public prosecutions has said.

Stephen Parkinson told the PA news agency: “We’ve all read or seen on the news reports of far-right groups publishing information about named individuals or immigration law firms, for instance, encouraging activity affecting those individuals. The fact that it’s organised groups that might be motivated by ideological reasons, the fact that they’re promoting potentially very serious offences — that’s the sort of instance where we might want to consider terrorism charges.”
A “hit list” of targets in Reading has been circulating on social media, including a mosque, all “p*** shops”, “and any other foreign c**** on the way”.

Thames Valley Police issued a statement saying it was monitoring a variety of sources including social media and reports from the public to identify planned protests, adding: “Should any planned protests or spontaneous incidents escalate into violent disorder seen elsewhere in the country, we are prepared and officers will swiftly and robustly respond and deal with those choosing to cause harm to our communities.”
The Reading Muslim organisation urged people to “remain alert” and “avoid being lured into provocations or disturbances”.
Three more arrests have been made following the disorder in Tamworth, which saw rioters try to set fire to a hotel believed to be housing asylum seekers.
Tamworth Police released footage of the arrests taking place, which are part of its investigation into the violent disorder in the Staffordshire town.
A network of far-right fight clubs has urged its members to participate in riots tonight.

Active Clubs, a group of small, fascist martial arts and fight clubs, began in the United States where they have been promoted by the neo-Nazi Robert Rundo, who was recently jailed for rioting. Clubs exist in England, Scotland and Northern Ireland. To join Active Club England, would-be members must be over 18 and “of European heritage”, the group’s Telegram account says.

The group’s Scottish wing, Active Club Scotland, included former members of the banned terrorist group National Action, the research group Hope Not Hate found, and members have previously been prosecuted for making bomb threats. As communities braced for violent disorder today, Active Club England issued advice to its members on how to take part, and how to avoid arrest.
Telegram has confirmed to BBC Verify that it is removing calls for violence in the UK.

“Moderators are actively monitoring the situation and are removing channels and posts containing calls to violence. Calls to violence are explicitly forbidden by Telegram’s terms of service,” the company said in a statement. The platform has reportedly been a vehicle for far-right groups to organise their protests across the country.
Businesses in the Jewellery Quarter of Birmingham shut early today as reports of a far-right protest planned outside of the Refugee and Migrant Centre on Frederick Street created a “ghost town”.

Workers at Top Jewellery, a gold business on neighbouring Warstone Lane, were boarding up the shopfront. “Our boss has just spent £20,000 on two new security doors; he would rather spend £120 to protect the shop than have to replace them if someone tries to smash it up,” explained Stan, an employee. “I do think these protesters are looking for trouble and would target anyone.”

At least three other jewellers had boarded up their windows, while several other shops and restaurants closed early. Andy, a barista at Urban Coffee, said: “We aren’t taking any risks… but at the same time I won’t let anyone intimidate me.”
Angela Rayner, the deputy prime minister, has said “it’s not a legitimate complaint to throw bricks at police” as she vowed those involved with riots “will be met with the law”.

She said: “Over 140 people have been charged so far and it’s right that our courts deal with that, and we’ve said that we will support the courts and will support the police in carrying out their duties. But people need to understand that if you throw missiles, if you attack people, if you incite hatred and violence, whether that’s online, or whether you’re offline, you will be met with the law because it is unlawful.
“We end up in a situation we have here where people’s lives were at risk and police officers’ lives were put at risk by a small minority of criminality and thuggish behaviour.”
A number of authorities have taken to social media to reassure residents that rumours being spread online of riots in their areas were “misinformation”.

In Lewisham, southeast London, the local Metropolitan Police Service said: “We understand there were rumours that shops were closing early today. We wish to reassure business owners and our community that shops and businesses in Lewisham remain open as usual and that there was spreading of misinformation online.”

Hackney council put out a statement to warn of “misinformation circulating regarding planned public disorder in Stoke Newington” but said the police have confirmed they had “no intelligence” to suggest that far-right rioters would be in the borough. Meanwhile North Tyneside council posted: “Social media posts about disorder in North Tyneside are not true. Northumbria police tell us that there is no intelligence of planned protest activity in North Tyneside and there are no ongoing incidents of disorder within North Tyneside.”
The director of public prosecutions, Stephen Parkinson, has said one case of alleged terrorism is “actively under consideration” following widespread disorder across the country.

He told the PA news agency: “No one’s been charged with a terrorism offence yet. I’m aware of one case which is actively under consideration. We’re working very closely with Counter Terrorism Police, so I know there are a number of inquiries that are potentially under way — that includes scouring the internet and social media, looking out for the potential for terrorism offences to be committed.”
Retweeting material which can stir up racial hatred can count as a criminal offence, the director of public prosecutions of England and Wales has warned.

Stephen Parkinson told Sky News: “The offence of incitement to racial hatred involves publishing or distributing material which is insulting or abusive which is intended to or likely to stir up racial hatred. So if you retweet that, you are republishing that and then potentially you are committing that offence. We do have dedicated police officers who are scouring social media to look for this material, and then follow up with identification, arrests and so forth.
“It is really serious. People might think they are not doing anything harmful — they are, and the consequences will be visited upon them.”
Businesses in areas listed as targets for riots are boarding up and closing early in case protests turn violent (Emma Yeomans writes).

In North Finchley, London, workers were seen boarding up shops while restaurants had their shutters down on Wednesday afternoon while police patrolled the area. An Audi dealership in Brent said it was closing at 4pm, and seeking to move its cars off the forecourt.

Estate agents in Walthamstow, east London, closed their offices and told staff to work from home, while the Nags Head pub nearby informed customers via social media they would be shut. In Essex, small businesses in Westcliff-on-Sea have boarded up their shopfronts ahead of planned action nearby and said police have been visiting local stores to offer support and advice.

Saira Hussain, who runs HAD, a small architectural practice with offices in Manchester, Burnley, Blackburn and north London, said one shop next door in central Manchester had had their windows smashed. She added: “I’m a third-generation British Pakistani. I was born here, studied here, trade here and employ people from this country. I bet I’ve contributed much more to this country than any of these people that are causing trouble. It would be nice to live and work in peace.”
Ofcom has urged social media companies to do more to deal with content stirring up hatred or provoking violence on Britain’s streets.

In an open letter, the watchdog said: “In a few months, new safety duties under the Online Safety Act will be in place, but you can act now — there is no need to wait to make your sites and apps safer for users.” The letter, signed by Gill Whitehead, Ofcom director for online safety, said it would publish further guidance “later this year”.

It added: “We expect continued engagement with companies over this period to understand the specific issues they face and we welcome the proactive approaches that have been deployed by some services in relation to these acts of violence across the UK.”
The wife of a Conservative councillor has been arrested and bailed for allegedly calling for hotels housing asylum seekers to be set alight (David Woode writes).

Lucie Connolly, 41, is said to have urged “mass deportations now”. In a post on Twitter/X on the day of the Southport stabbings she allegedly wrote: “Set fire to all the f***ing hotels full of the bastards for all I care, while you’re at it take the treacherous government [and] politicians with them. I feel physically sick knowing what these families will now have to endure. If that makes me racist, so be it.”

The childminder, who is married to Raymond Connolly, who represents the Delapre and Rushmere ward in Northampton, was arrested on suspicion of inciting racial hatred on Tuesday and taken into custody. She was later released on bail. Connolly, who resigned her registration with the regulator Ofsted, later apologised for comments. She said she had acted on “false and malicious” information.
A woman has appeared in court accused of sending a threatening message suggesting blowing up “a mosque with adults inside”, a court official said.

Julie Sweeney, 53, of Lawtongate Estate, Church Lawton, Cheshire, appeared before Warrington magistrates’ court charged with sending communication threatening death or serious harm. Court papers allege that on Saturday the defendant “sent a message that conveyed a threat of death or serious harm, namely, suggesting to ‘blow up a mosque with adults inside’, intending, or being reckless as to whether, an individual encountering the message would fear that the threat would be carried out”.
Sweeney has not entered a plea to the charge and has been remanded in custody until a hearing at Chester crown court on August 14.
A court was told that a man who pleaded guilty to violent disorder had travelled from West Yorkshire to take part in unrest in Manchester on Saturday.

Laura Peers, the prosecutor, said a “large group of far-right protesters” were seen engaging in an “altercation with one black male”, which was filmed by members of the group and uploaded on social media. Peers told Manchester magistrates’ court that Liam Ryan, 28, of Thirkleby Royd, Bradford, had “played an active role in the disorder”, adding: “He was seen on the footage aiming a punch towards the male involved.”

Jane Hamilton, the district judge, remanded Ryan, who was shaking as he wiped tears away with a tissue after pleading guilty, into custody and ordered him to appear at Manchester crown court on August 14.

A man has pleaded guilty to inciting racial hatred by using racist language on a livestream he broadcast to “millions of people” from outside a hotel in Stockport thought to contain asylum seekers on Monday.

Aaron Johnson, 32, of Criterion Street, North Reddish, pleaded guilty at Manchester magistrates’ court to distributing images intended to stir up racial hatred. Laura Peers, prosecuting, said Johnson told members of staff at the hotel that “he would smash their face in”. She said that in the livestream he “repeatedly refers to migrants in a derogatory manner” and used racist language.

Jane Hamilton, the district judge, told Johnson: “You also made reference to the children who were unfortunately murdered in Southport — that had nothing to do with asylum seekers or anything else. The man who did that was born in this country.”
Johnson was remanded into custody and will be sentenced at Minshull Street crown court on August 21.
A guide to walking free from arrest produced by a far-right organisation was spread around social media, The Times can reveal (Emma Yeomans writes).

The document, produced by a now-defunct far-right organisation with the support of Nick Griffin, chairman of the BNP, includes advice on hiding evidence of extremist views from police, as well as how to physically resist arrest, and what to do in police custody.

It accuses police officers of lying in court, and describes the police as “enemies” and “overpaid boot-boys”. The inflammatory material, which was shared by far-right members in Telegram groups used to arrange riots, will add to concerns of public disorder.

So far more than 400 people have been arrested in connection with the riots and nearly 100 charged. The charges so far include violent disorder, resisting an officer, affray and stirring racial hatred.
A 16-year-old boy from Tamworth has been charged as officers continue to investigate Sunday’s attack on a Holiday Inn Express in the town.

The boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, has been charged with violent disorder and assault by beating of an emergency worker. He is due to appear at the North Staffordshire Justice Centre today.
Two men have been arrested in connection with the same disorder, a 28-year-old and a 43-year-old both from Tamworth.

Elsewhere, Alex Fraser, 20, of Oldham Road, Manchester, and Matthew Wilson, 31, of Parrock Street, Rossendale, Lancashire, have been charged with racially aggravated assault and public order offences in Manchester at the weekend.
They have been remanded into custody to appear at Manchester and Salford magistrates’ court later today.
A lot of the disorder is “low-level criminals joining in the trouble” as an excuse to commit violence and looting, according to a police source.
The source told the PA news agency that the events are “not particularly sophisticated” with “definitely some sort of organisation” at a local level but “not necessarily” on a national level.
“A lot of what we’re seeing is locals reacting to what they’re seeing on social media, what they’re seeing outside in their streets and just joining in,” the source said.

“Quite a lot of forces have reported that it’s not actually right-wing or left-wing, sometimes a lot of it is actually just low-level criminals who they already know about joining the trouble, using it as an excuse to commit violence and looting.”
Just Stop Oil has announced it is pausing protests in order not to stretch police resources “until the immediate threats to safety have been dealt with appropriately”.

A spokesperson for the group said: “The civil unrest the country is experiencing is a taste of what science is telling us will happen, as climate chaos accelerates and makes the preservation of a stable society untenable.”
Just Stop Oil supporters will be joining peaceful counter-protests and taking part in clean-ups because their “primary focus is to resist fascism”.
The Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) has called for Robert Jenrick to apologise after he said people should be immediately arrested for shouting “allahu akbar” in the streets of London.

Asked about “two-tier policing” on Sky News this morning, Jenrick admitted he had been critical of the police during pro-Palestine protests and said: “I thought it was quite wrong that someone could chant allahu akbar on the streets of London and not be immediately arrested.”
The MCB accused Jenrick of reaching for “Islamophobic rhetoric” and emboldening the far-right.
Jenrick later admitted on Twitter/X that the phrase is “spoken peacefully” by many but shared a video of “aggressive chanting” of the phrase and argued it is “intimidatory and threatening”.
“Extremists routinely abuse common expressions for their own shameful ends,” he added.
Owners of convenience stores are being urged to “err on the side of caution” to protect staff and customers.
James Lowman, the chief executive of the Association of Convenience Stores, told Sky News: “It is about, fundamentally, that people are more important than property.”

He said that retailers who had been trading in places such as Middlesbrough and Hull described the disorder as “the worst thing they have ever known in their communities”. Their main response is looking to close early ahead of planned protests, Lowman said.

Just under half of convenience store owners in the UK define themselves as being of Asian or British Asian ethnicity, he said, adding: “For those people in particular, the undercurrent of racism that they’ve probably had to live with throughout their lives, this really brings that to the surface.”
Police chiefs are braced for more than 100 planned gatherings and over 30 counter protests across almost all parts of England today (David Woode writes).

Activity is anticipated in 41 out of 43 police forces areas and “some will be worst affected than others”.A policing source said: “We think it’s looking like a credible picture. Whether it reaches 100 we don’t know but there will be dozens and dozens [of gatherings].

“A lot of what we’re seeing is locals reacting to what’s on social media and outside in their streets and they’re joining in. [Much] of it is low level criminals using it as an excuse to commit violence. There is a level of local co-ordination and planning which is not particularly sophisticated.”
It’s understood that police are monitoring Facebook, Twitter/X and TikTok and “trawling video platforms for evidential purposes”.
A 32-year-old man has been charged with distributing a recording intending to stir up racial hatred.
The CPS authorised the charge against Aaron Johnson of North Reddish, Stockport, relating to alleged filming that took place outside a hotel in the town on Monday.
He will appear at Manchester magistrates’ court today.
The three men sentenced today are the “tip of the iceberg”, the CPS has said.

Speaking outside Liverpool crown court, crown prosecutor Jonathan Egan said they were “just the start of what will be a very painful process for many who foolishly chose to involve themselves in violent unrest”.

He added that “disturbing images seen across the country manipulated by agitators both in person and online while local families still grieve their loved ones is an unforgivable and selfish act that each person sentenced today will have to live with”.
Egan warned that many more people will be sent to prison for a “long time”.
“Violence, rioting and aggression will never be tolerated in this country,” he vowed. “Whatever your motivation you will be swiftly punished.”
Two more men have been sentenced after admitting violent disorder in Liverpool on Saturday.
Declan Geiran, 29, of Kelso Road, Liverpool, was sentenced to 30 months in prison after he pleaded guilty to violent disorder in Liverpool on Saturday and sending a malicious communication last year.
Liam Riley, 40, of Walton Road, Liverpool, has been sentenced to 20 months in prison after he admitted violent disorder and racially aggravated behaviour in Liverpool on Saturday.
Both were sentenced at Liverpool crown court.
The first person has been sentenced in relation to the disorder in Southport the day after the stabbings.
Derek Drummond, 58, of Pool Street, Southport, has been sentenced to three years in prison after he admitted violent disorder and assaulting an emergency worker in Southport on Tuesday July 30.
He was sentenced at Liverpool crown court.
Britain’s most senior police officer has described accusations of two-tier policing as “complete nonsense” and claimed criticism of frontline officers is putting their safety at risk.
Critics including Elon Musk, the owner of Twitter/X, have claimed the police response to the riots has been “one-sided”.

Sir Mark Rowley, the Metropolitan Police commissioner, said on Wednesday: “It’s complete nonsense. We have commentators from either end of the political spectrum who like to throw accusations of bias at the police because we stand in the middle, we operate independently under the law without fear or favour.”

Rowley, who did not name Musk, added: “The serious voices who echo those are of more concern to me, because they legitimise the violence that the officers I’m sending on mutual aid today will face on the streets. They are putting them at risk.”
A total of 140 people have been charged following disorder across the country, according to the Crown Prosecution Service.

Nick Price, Director of Legal Services for the CPS, said: “In addition to more than 120 individuals charged yesterday, we have charged a further 20 people with a range of offences following the continued unrest in parts of the country.

“The Crown Prosecution Service will continue to work alongside police to build the strongest possible cases, authorise rapid charging decisions and ensure those involved in disorder are brought before the courts.”
At least 428 people have been arrested in connection with violent protests and the figure is set to rise.
Six people aged between 14 and 41 have been arrested following a number of race-related hate crimes and disorder across Belfast.
A 15-year-old boy is due to appear before Belfast magistrates’ court today charged with two counts of riot and possession of a weapon with intent to commit an indictable offence.
Charges and arrests continue to be made in England with several people appearing in court today.

Sadiq Khan condemned the “disorder, racism and violence” seen in the past week. Addressing reports of far-right groups targeting locations in the capital, Khan vowed: “If you break the law, action will be taken against you.”

He added: “I know the shocking scenes have left many Muslims and minority ethnic communities scared and fearful, so I ask my fellow Londoners to check on their friends and neighbours and show them that care and compassion is what Londoners are all about.
“In London, we have zero tolerance for racism, Islamophobia, antisemitism or any form of hate and we pride ourselves on being open, diverse and welcoming of all faiths and backgrounds.”

Far-right groups have claimed the police are engaged in “two-tier policing’ — cracking down harder on white protesters than those from ethnic minorities. The police have denied the claim and No 10 has said it is a “non-issue”.
Asked whether he saw evidence of “two-tier policing” during his time in the role, Sir Thomas Winsor said: “No. It doesn’t exist — policing is even handed.”
He added that when politicians and others repeatedly talk about “two-tier policing” it “increases a perception of unfairness which is not correct”.
Winsor reminded listeners of the oath which every police officer takes to “accord equal respect to all people according to law, and that’s what they do”.

Sir Thomas Winsor, former chief inspector of constabulary, said there should be “criminal liability” for senior managers at social media companies for tolerating “harmful material” and incitement to commit crime.
He also called for a licencing system in the UK similar to that for public infrastructure such as energy, telecommunications, water and transport. He said fines are not enough.

Winsor told LBC that he noted in his State of Police Report in 2018 that some social media companies now own and operate “significant pieces of public infrastructure” therefore “stewardship of that infrastructure is not purely a matter of commercial freedom”.
He added that Elon Musk, who owns Twitter/X, should “stick to batteries, cars and rockets” and leave it to the UK authorities to deal with the “protection of safety and security of our communities”.
Inquests are to be opened into the deaths of the three girls who were fatally stabbed in Southport.

Their inquests will be formally opened at Bootle Town Hall in Merseyside today.

Five other children and two adults were seriously injured in the attack. All the children who were injured have now been discharged from hospital.

Video showed a mob confront a lone white man on a terrace of the Clumsy Swan in Yardley. They could be seen punching him to the ground and repeatedly kicking him. Initial eyewitness reports point to a waterspout, a rare but increasingly common phenomenon in the Mediterranean, as the cause of the sinking of Bayesian.

These intense weather events, which appear as whirling columns of air and mist, are effectively tornadoes that are formed over the sea, rather than on land. They are associated with severe thunderstorms and are often accompanied by high winds and seas, hail and dangerous lightning.
The biggest risk comes in the “knockdown”, when the wind and waves have enough energy to tear off a boat’s mast.
Waterspouts were once rare, but have become an increasingly common phenomenon in the region related to the heating of the Mediterranean, according to the Italian meteorological society.

Tornados, once rare, are an increasingly common phenomenon in the Mediterranean, a weather expert said.

“A so-called funnel cloud forms, generating winds of up to 200km/h which can create a waterspout at sea by sucking water into the air,” Luca Mercalli, president of the Italian Meteorological Society, said.
“The event can be restricted to a few hundred metres and be over in ten minutes. These are increasingly common in Italy although we do not have hard data.
“They are generally related to the heating of the Mediterranean, which pumps more energy into all meteorological phenomena,” he said.
Warm, moist air, an unstable atmosphere and multi-directional wind flows are all conditions that make tornados more likely to occur.

Generally, tornados and waterspouts are more frequent in late summer and autumn than in other seasons. However, it’s not possible to put the causes for any individual weather event down to climate change alone.
